channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: U.S. Navy Escorting British Ships Through Strait After Detention Dispute
item.description: The Navy has been accompanying United States-flagged ships through the strait in response to last week’s detention of the MV Maersk Tigris by Iranian Revolutionary Guards patrol boats.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Parliament Approves Overhaul Aimed at Improving Political Stability
item.description: Italy’s Parliament gave final approval on Monday to a new electoral law championed by Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, despite furious objections from the opposition and some members of the governing Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: India: 20 Die as Bus Plunges Into Gorge
item.description: A crowded minibus skidded off a highway in central India and plunged down a gorge Monday afternoon, catching fire on the way, according to a district police official.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: Militants Destroy Prized Site
item.description: Jihadists have destroyed a mausoleum in central Mali that had been proposed as a United Nations World Heritage site, leaving behind a warning that they will come after all those who do not follow their strict version of Islam.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: World’s Youngest Nation Is ‘at Grave Risk,’ Kerry Warns
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry warned Monday that the violent civil conflict, mass displacement and deepening food crisis roiling South Sudan was threatening its future.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Far-Right Party in France Tries to Push Jean-Marie Le Pen, Provocative Founder, to the Margins
item.description: The National Front’s decision to distance itself from Mr. Le Pen comes as the party tries to win favor with a mainstream electorate.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Jean-Marie Le Pen may be stripped of his honorary title as National Front president.

item.title: Akcakale Journal: Fertilizer, Also Suited for Bombs, Flows to ISIS Territory From Turkey
item.description: The fertilizer ammonium nitrate, which was used in explosives at the Oklahoma City federal building in 1995, has been moving into an extremist-controlled Syrian town in what appear to be large quantities.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laborers loaded ammonium nitrate last week at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria. The compound, a common fertilizer, has also been used by terrorists to create explosives.

item.title: Syrian Forces Kill Attackers in Damascus
item.description: One armed man blew himself up, state news outlets reported, in a type of clash that remains rare in the capital even after over four years of war.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Some Progress Is Reported in Informal Afghan-Taliban Talks
item.description: While not binding, agreements on matters such as the Constitution and the presence of foreign troops raised hopes about the long deadlocked process.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: ‘Tale of Two Cities’ Widens Worldwide for Children, Study Shows
item.description: Save the Children said in two-thirds of the countries surveyed, poorest urban children are at least twice as likely to die as wealthy counterparts.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Nepal’s Young Men, Lost to Migration, Then a Quake
item.description: Healthy young men were leaving to find work in great waves before the quake. Now, even before the dead are fully counted, it is clear that Nepal cannot afford the losses.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many bodies prepared for cremation last week in Kathmandu were of young men from Gongabu, a common stopover for Nepali migrant workers headed overseas.

item.title: Israeli Foreign Minister Says He Won’t Join Netanyahu’s New Government
item.description: Avigdor Lieberman’s decision is unlikely to block a coalition by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, but it would leave him with a razor-thin majority in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Soldier Becomes Unlikely Face of Ethiopian-Israeli Discontent
item.description: Demas Fikadey, 21, does not see himself as a symbol, but has emerged as one since his beating by police officers set off an outburst of anger.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Ethiopian-Israelis confronted Israeli security forces in Tel Aviv on Sunday. Israeli leaders appealed for calm after a demonstration in Tel Aviv on Sunday night in which 56 police officers were injured and 43 protesters were arrested.

item.title: Espresso? Now the International Space Station Is Fully Equipped
item.description: Samantha Cristoforetti, the first Italian woman in orbit, used a special “ISSpresso” machine and an antigravity cup to satisfy a thirst and curiosity.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Samantha Cristoforetti of Italy sipped an espresso over the weekend aboard the International Space Station.

item.title: 3 Protesters Dead in Burundi After Clashes With Police
item.description: Hundreds of people took to the streets of the capital, Bujumbura, to demonstrate after the president’s party nominated him for a third term.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Europe Moving Toward Single Digital Market
item.description: If proposals become law, companies like Netflix could offer services without making separate licensing deals in 28 countries.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jakub Klena, who lives in Bratislava, Slovakia, cannot watch Netflix legally there. “I don’t want to illegally download these shows,” he said. “I have a real job and can pay for them.”

item.title: Britain’s Campaign Finance Laws Leave Parties With Idle Money
item.description: Few countries combine Britain’s fascination with American-style politics with campaign finance rules so stringent that they might seem better suited to City Council races.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: A Conservative Party billboard in Bedworth, England, east of Birmingham. The region is an important battleground in national elections this Thursday.

item.title: Nepalis in New York Improvise a Relief Effort for Earthquake Victims
item.description: The small but fast-growing population, despite a lack of well-established community institutions, has used technology and social media to help its homeland.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sherpa Collections Inc., a cellphone store in Elmhurst, Queens, has become a collection site for donations to be sent to Nepal, where an earthquake on April 25 left more than 7,000 people dead.

item.title: As the Euro Slides, a Coin Meets Its Waterloo
item.description: A commemorative coin minted by Belgium raised hackles in France, a small example of the continuing bumps on the road to European unity.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Maroesjka Lavigne for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Belgian Royal Mint minted a 2-euro coin memorializing the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Waterloo.

item.title: World Briefing: Bus Crash in Central India Kills More Than 20
item.description: The driver lost control of the minibus and it skidded off a highway, plunged down a gorge and then caught fire on the way in Madhya Pradesh State.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR
